intro: Commiphora roxburghii var. serratifolia, commonly known as the Indian bdellium or serrated myrrh, is a species of flowering plant in the family Burseraceae. It is native to regions of India, Nepal, and Bhutan, where it thrives in dry, tropical climates. The plant is characterized by its aromatic resinous sap, which has been traditionally used in incense and medicinal applications. Its leaves are serrated, giving it the varietal name "serratifolia," and it produces small, inconspicuous yellow flowers. The tree can grow up to 10 meters tall and is often found in dry forests and scrublands.
